main package¶

Submodules¶

qthmi.main.alarmserver module¶

Handle alarms

Provides an AlarmServer class which is able to handle alarms. It is intended for HMI software where alarm handling is often necessary.

The following features are provided:
  • defining alarms with numbers and alarm texts
  • alarms are handled and identified by their alarm number
  • alarms can come and leave
  • alarms can be acknowledged and cleared by the user

In addition to the basic AlarmServer class there is an AlarmServerModel class which implements the model/view pattern used by the Qt framework. So this class can be used as a model for QTableView or QListView.

class qthmi.main.alarmserver.Alarm(alarm_nr, text)[source]¶

An instance of this class represents a defined or active alarm.

Variables:
  • alarm_nr (int) – unique alarm number, used as key value
  • text (basestring) – alarm text
  • time_coming (datetime) – time the alarm started
  • time_going (datetime) – time the alarm finished
  • time_acknowledged (datetime) – time when alarm got acknowledged by the user
  • counter (int) – number of times the alarm has been raised since active
  • is_acknowledged (bool) – shows if the alarm has been acknowledged
  • is_active (bool) – shows if the alarm is currently active
acknowledge()[source]¶

Acknowledge the alarm by setting time_acknowledge and the acknowledged property.

clear()[source]¶

Clear the alarm by setting back all instance variables to the init values.

exception qthmi.main.alarmserver.AlarmNotDefinedError[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

class qthmi.main.alarmserver.AlarmServer[source]¶

An alarm server with the possibility to define alarms, raise, acknowledge and clear them.

Variables:
  • current_alarms (list) – list of current alarms
  • defined_alarms (dict) – dictionary of all defined alarms, key is the alarm number
acknowledge(alarm_nr)[source]¶

Acknowledge a specific alarm identified via alarm_nr. :param int alarm_nr: alarm identifiert

acknowledge_all()[source]¶

Acknowledge all current alarms.

alarm_coming(alarm_nr)[source]¶

Set the alarm with the given number to active. If the alarm is not active but in the current alarm list the counter will be raised by one. If the alarm is not in the current alarm list it will be inserted. The C{time_coming} attribute is set to the current time if the alarm has been inactive.

Parameters:alarm_nr (int) – alarm identifier
alarm_going(alarm_nr)[source]¶

Set the alarm with the given number to inactive. The C{time_going} attribute is set to the current time if the alarm has been active.

Parameters:alarm_nr (int) – alarm identifier
clear(alarm_nr)[source]¶

Remove the alarm with the given number from the list of current alarms. All instance variables will be set to their initial value.

Parameters:alarm_nr (int) – alarm identifier
clear_all()[source]¶

Remove all alarms from the list of current alarms.

define_alarm(alarm_nr, alarm_text)[source]¶

Define a new alarm and add it to the list C{defined_alarms}.

Parameters:
  • alarm_nr (int) – key value for accessing the alarm
  • alarm_text (basestring) – text describing the alarm
unacknowledged_alarms[source]¶

list of all unacknowledged alarms

Return type:list
class qthmi.main.alarmserver.AlarmWord(tag, alarmserver, offset=0)[source]¶

Bases: qthmi.main.widgets.HMIObject

Hold the value of an alarm word and raise alarms for each alarm bit.

Variables:
  • alarmserver (qthmi.main.Alarmserver) – alarm server with the defined alarms
  • offset (int) – offset added to the alarm number
check()[source]¶

Check alarm word for active alarms identified by their bit number. Call alarm_coming function of the alarmserver for each active alarm.

main.connector module¶

Abstract class for PLC connection

class qthmi.main.connector.AbstractPLCConnector[source]¶

Bases: PyQt4.QtCore.QObject, object

Connector with buffered PLC access. The access is not done directly via PLC addresses but instead with Tags. Data is exchanged with the PLC when the C{poll()} function is called or C{autopoll} is enabled.

Variables:
  • tags – holds the Tag objects, the key is the tag name
  • poll_interval – interval for auto-polling in ms
add_tag(tag)[source]¶

Add a Tag to the list. :type tag: Tag :return: tag

cycletime[source]¶
poll()[source]¶

Exchange data with PLC.

If a Tag value has been modified in the GUI the value is first written to the PLC and then read again.

The SIGNAL C{polled()} is emitted when finished.

read_from_plc(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶
remove_tag(tag_name)[source]¶

Remove a Tag from the list. :type tag_name: str :param tag_name: name of the Tag

start_autopoll(poll_interval)[source]¶

Enable auto-polling data.

Parameters:poll_interval (int) – interval for autopolling in ms
stop_autopoll()[source]¶

Disable auto-polling data.

write_to_plc(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶
class qthmi.main.connector.BufferConnector(connector)[source]¶

Bases: qthmi.main.connector.AbstractPLCConnector

Connect to other Connectors.

Buffer Tag values for Plotting or Logging independently from the poll interval of the original Connector. So all processdata can still be collected continuously while some HMIWidgets like plotters or loggers are only refreshed when asked for.

Variables:connector – data source
read_from_plc(address, datatype)[source]¶
write_to_plc(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

main.plot module¶

Realtime data plotting¶

Plot PLC data in Realtime.

For HMIPlot to work we need the following packages:

>>> import sys
>>> from PyQt4.QtGui import QApplication
>>> from qthmi.main.connector import AbstractPLCConnector
>>> from qthmi.main.tag import Tag
>>> app = QApplication(sys.argv)

Now we create a new Connector and the HMIPlot object:

>>> connector = AbstractPLCConnector()
>>> plot = HMIPlot(connector)
>>> type(plot)
<class 'qthmi.main.plot.HMIPlot'>

The C{add_observer()} method is used to creat an Observer object collecting data from the given Tag:

>>> tag1 = connector.add_tag(Tag("tag1", 0))
>>> plot.add_observer(tag1, "Tag1", ax=0, style="b-")
>>> type(plot.observers[0])
<class 'qthmi.main.plot.Observer'>

The HMIPlot object is inherited from C{QWidget} and can be displayed on its own by calling the C{show()} function or embedded in a second QWidget object.

class qthmi.main.plot.HMIPlot(connector, parent=None, buffer_size=100)[source]¶

main.tag module¶

class qthmi.main.tag.ScaledTag(name, address, plc_datatype=None, datatype=<type 'float'>)[source]¶

Bases: qthmi.main.tag.Tag

Tag that supplies a converted, scaled and offset value

>>> tag = ScaledTag("scaled_tag", 0)
>>> tag.scale_factor = 2
>>> tag.scale_offset = 5
>>> tag._raw_value = 10
>>> tag.value
25.0
Variables:
  • scale – factor for scaling the raw_value
  • offset – offset added to the raw_value
value[source]¶

converted, scaled and offset value for use in GUI

If value is set the new value will be transferred to the PLC the next time the C{poll()} function of the C{BufferedPLCConnector} object is called.

class qthmi.main.tag.Tag(name, address, plc_datatype=None, datatype=<type 'float'>)[source]¶

Bases: PyQt4.QtCore.QObject, object

An instance of Tag represents a buffered connection between GUI and PLC

Variables:
  • name – tag name
  • address – PLC memory address
  • datatype – python datatype
  • dirty – is set if the tag value has been changed
  • plc_datatype – identifier for the datatype the data is stored in the PLC
  • raw_value – the raw PLC value
raw_value[source]¶

The raw PLC value

value[source]¶

If value is set the new value will be transferred to the PLC the next time the C{poll()} function of the C{BufferedPLCConnector} object is called.

qthmi.main.util.timeit(method)[source]¶

Decorator for measuring execution time of a function. Usage:

>>> @timeit
... def f1():
...     time.sleep(1)
...     print 'f1'
